Title: üñº 2025 will be the last year of legal operation of most aircraft...
Description: 2025 will be the last year of legal operation of most aircraft in the Russian aircraft fleetEquipment failures in Russian aircraft are becoming more and more frequent. Thus, from December 1, 2024 to January 20, 2025, aircraft from the Russian fleet experienced 11 engine failures. It was previously reported that last year the number of air incidents in the Russian Federation increased by 25%. At least 90% of these were due to system failures, mainly engines and chassis. If the West does not lift sanctions, the situation will worsen this year, experts are sure, interviewed Radio Liberty. Vessels require a thorough inspection - C Check - every 18-24 months, and D Check - every 6-12 years. This cannot be done without direct cooperation with aircraft manufacturers. -I don‚Äôt have exact data on the service life of all Russian aircraft, but 2025 will be the last year of legal operation of most of them,- said a Russian aviation safety expert.Russian airlines are trying to extend the life of aircraft by smuggling certified parts from the US and Europe, as well as resorting to unofficial technical inspections and reducing the frequency of flights. Today, the Russian aircraft fleet consists of about 700 foreign and 150 Sukhoi Superjet. However, sanctions also affect the production of domestic aircraft, since they also depend on Western parts. Even though they can pass C and D Check in the Russian Federation, airlines will still have to resort to finding Western parts for modernization. -Both foreign aircraft and the Superjet will eventually be taken out of service due to parts shortages. Superjet will last only a year longer,- another flight safety expert told the publication.Russia is pinning its hopes on the new domestic MC-21 aircraft, but the Russian Federation does not have a replacement for American engines. If China can supply Russia with reliable engines, the MC-21 may have a future, but not before 2029, experts say. -As a result, China will receive a plane for rogue countries - Iran, North Korea and Russia,- one of the interlocutors concluded.

Description: The Ministry of Finance proposed to monitor tax residency through banking applicationsThe Ministry of Finance of the Russian Federation proposed to take into account the frequency of use of banking applications abroad when checking tax residency, write Vedomosti. If a client accesses the bank‚Äôs electronic services from abroad more than half the time over the course of six months, this may become the basis for requesting data on his tax status. Banks will be required to check with such users information about residency and transfer it to the Federal Tax Service. However, the very fact of using a mobile bank abroad will not automatically confirm a change in tax status - they do not plan to use geolocation data for these purposes. Currently, tax residents of Russia are considered to be those who spend at least 183 days in the country during the year. The loss of this status means that income received in the Russian Federation will be taxed at a rate of 30%, with the exception of remote employees of Russian companies.

Description: In Yekaterinburg, a 16-year-old girl was forcibly married off. Sledkom became interested in the caseAfter information spread in local public pages that a 16-year-old girl was forcibly married by her parents to a 24-year-old man, the head of the Investigative Committee of Russia, Alexander Bastrykin, ordered to open a criminal case on the fact of forced marriage and restriction of freedom of a minor. This was reported by the department's press service. The incident occurred in February 2024. The girl refused to marry by consent, after which her parents, belonging to the Yazidi community, allegedly beat her and forcibly took her to the groom's house, where she was deprived of freedom, the opportunity to study and communicate with relatives and friends. The marriage was concluded only according to tradition, but not in the registry office.Girl's friends toldE1 that she was under constant control in her husband's house, she was forbidden to continue her studies, her phone was monitored and she was forbidden to leave the house. Five years ago, the groom's family already a tragedy occurred: the man's younger sister committed suicide at the age of 16 when they tried to marry her off to a 50-year-old man. The girl's relatives claim that she was happy in her marriage, calling the accusations -slander.- The head of the public organization -Yazidis of the Urals,- Georgy Asoev, said that the couple lives in peace and harmony, and called the complaints -nonsense.- He emphasized that in the 21st century, forced marriage is impossible, and called not to interfere in family affairs. Nurzida Bensgier, director of the Interethnic Information Center in Yekaterinburg, also commented on the situation. She noted that in diasporas outside their country, the desire to preserve national identity, faith and traditions is especially pronounced, especially in matters of marriage and funerals. According to a study by the human rights organization Ad Rem published in 2024, 4,453 marriages involving underage girls were registered in the country in 2021 alone. However, official statistics do not reflect the real scale of the problem, since many such unions are not officially registered.Yazidis are an ethno-confessional group of Kurds living mainly in northwestern Iraq, northern and northeastern Syria. In Russia, according to the 2010 census, there are more than 40 thousand of them.
